item.description: This game comes from a company called Chad Valley and was produced in the mid 1920's. The object of the game was to shoot down and therefore sink your opponents sailing ships using balls fired from two working lead cannons.

All the thrills of baseball without leaving your house.

Speed Baseball uses a combination of cards and a die roll to determine the outcome of each hitter. As well as normal play each person has 3 special actions a game that they can take which have a huge affect on the game. These actions range from pinch hitting to a double play.

The game be downloaded for free from the publishers official website http://www.spunkychicken.com/baseball.shtml

Air Race is a game involving the delivery of mail around the world in the shortest time possible. The game is for 2 - 4 players. Each player uses destination cards in order to determine where one needs to deliver the mail to. Finishing ones deliveries in the shortest amount of time is the goal of the game. Rolling the dice is the method of movement. This is a Chad Valley game from the mid 1930's

A board game for up to seven players, the object of the game for one of the players to become a Millionaire. The journey of players around the board is subject to advantage and penalty squares and a pack of playing cards with similar subject matter. the game features a lovely board loaded with period illustrations. The game was produced by Wm. Sessions Ltd.of York, England sometime in the early 1940s.

Unusual game consisting of six character heads and two lithographed Yo-Yo style discs. The object is to place the disc over the head and roll it it round the perimeter back to the lithographed bee start position without it falling off. That task is a pretty difficult thing to do. Characters are Jack (sailor HMS Watt.), Punch (Punch & Judy), Joey (Clown), Algy, Bertie and Colonel Bogey (cartoon or comic characters).

From the box:

"Py is a new exciting math game.
For all levels from kindergarten to college
Exercise your creativity and sharpen your mind
Great for family entertainment
Play by yourself or with others
Build a dazzling 3-D pyramid while you play
Intensity piles up as the game progresses
Create your own versions of the game"

Instructions include rules for five games: Connect color, Plus-Minus, All Operations, Combinations, & Squares.

Made in Bettendorf, Iowa.

name.value: Red Russia: The Russian Civil War 1918-1921

item.description:
As the Avalanche Press website explains, Red Russia uses a similar system to Soldier Kings: The Seven Years War Worldwide in simulating the Russian Civil War. Players represent up to four factions: the Reds (Communists), Siberian Whites (monarchists), Southern Whites, or Northern Whites. Each turn represents three months, and the game begins in Summer of 1918 and concludes, should one player not win outright, in the Spring 1921 turn. This 3-4 hour game thus lasts a maximum of twelve turns.

Players command infantry and cavalry armies, and for some factions fleets and aircraft. Leaders assist these units in movement and combat over land areas and sea zones. Each land area is rated for the amount of money and manpower it generates each turn. Manpower represents not just fresh recruits for armies, but also the things made with human labor: food, uniforms, weapons and so on. Factions thus use manpower to rebuild forces, and money to finance their actions. Combat is conducted by rolling dice, one for each attack factor, with hits reducing them in strength or eliminating them outright. A good general lets you roll more dice. Each area is also rated for its garrison strength; to capture it, you have to defeat the garrison troops through siege (in addition to driving off any enemy armies there).

Finally, to keep the game from becoming too "Risk"-like, players can play various event cards. Having the ability to fight through adversity makes one a powerful adversary in Red Russia.

item.description:
This is primarily an educational tool to structure learning about starting and operating a business. It is not intended to be played in a single sitting, but instead paces, adds random elements, and "keeps score" over the span of a entire business or economics class. It was created by a student group at North Central College in Naperville IL ("...just 29 miles from downtown Chicago." per to game).

Students will create business goal for a cookie making firm, eventually describing marketing, financial, and operational plans. The game tests these plans through the use of randomly drawn cards that create variations and alternatives for the students to cope with and learn from.

The production value is decent, with a fully mounted folding board. The documentation included with the game is excellent. There is a teacher's manual, blank and example business plans, blank cards of all four types to allow customization, and an instruction sheet for playing the game.

"An Exciting Way to Discover Black Heritage!"

This is a well-produced game that tests the players' knowledge of famous black people, black history, and black culture, with a predominantly American focus. The primary goal of the game is to score points by answering questions on the above subjects, with individual turn actions keyed by a basic roll-and-move mechanic.

The significant twist in the game is that each player takes one of twenty cards sets, each set consisting of 11 cards. Ten are clue cards related to a single black historical figure or celebrity. Another card in each set has the person's name and picture. During the game, the other players have the opportunity privately or publicly hear the clues and try to guess the character. The clues are divulged based on the players answers to toss-up questions on cards ("Words of Wisdom" and "Go Back to your Roots"), drawn when they land on the corresponding squares. Other squares allow free guessing of secret identities, answering questions for additional points, and other more typical roll-and-move actions. Points for answers/guesses are tallied on paper for as the game progresses.

This game appears to have a good balance between movement, deduction, and trivia mechanics. An unfortunate rule is that players who have their secret identities guessed are then out of the game, so it would help to have the most obscure figure possible. (There were two of twenty I was completely unfamiliar with, and a couple more I needed a clue to recognize.)

There will not be much replay after all the IDs have been used...but if that happens the game will have largely succeeded in it primary educational goal.

The abstract game of Qwirkle consists of 108 wooden blocks with six different shapes in six different colors. There is no board, players simply use an available flat surface.

Players begin the game with six blocks. The start player places blocks of a single matching attribute (color or shape but not both) on the table. Thereafter, a player adds blocks adjacent to at least one previously played block. The blocks must all be played in a line and match, without duplicates, either the color or shape of the previous block.

Players score one point for each block played plus all blocks adjacent. It is possible for a block to score in more than one direction. If a player completes a line containing all six shapes or colors, an additional six points are scored. The player then refills his hand to six blocks.

The game ends when the draw bag is depleted and one player plays all of his remaining blocks, earning a six point bonus. The player with the high score wins.

item.description:
(From Firefight Games website)
"Resistance is not Futile" covers the Insurrection of the Warsaw Ghetto in April 1943. With most of its remaining population already having endured years of privation and growing squalor, mass deportations, and learning that soon the Nazis would be back to send the remainder to Concentration Camps, an insurrection broke out on the eve of Adolf Hitler’s birthday. Local SS commander, Jurgen Stroop, believed the troops he had on-hand would make for a quick end to this impudent act of defiance by the Jews and the Polish Home Army members who choose to rise up against the Third Reich. His underestimation of the Jewish and Polish defenders was a costly mistake, as the fight lasted for weeks and cost the Germans and their fascist allies dearly."

Firefight Games had to suspend sales of this game temporarily after it prompted wild accusations of antisemitism against the designer. According to a post on Consimworld by Paul Rohrbaugh, sales have since resumed after consultations with lawyers, while legal proceedings are going ahead with the slanderers.

The game has also been sent to the Curator of the Holocaust Museum for review.

Map scale: 100 yards per inch
Counter scale: squad/platoon 
Game turn: 2 or 3 days

Casino Six
The ultimate game of chance.

Casino Six brings the challenge and excitement of six real casino games into you home. It's family fun for adults and older children - all in a simplified form, so even beginners can play. For more experienced players (and bold novices!) authentic Craps and Roulette layouts can be found. Games can be expanded to your liking.

Players advance through the Casino, trying their luck and testing their skill at six games in the following order:
Slots
Blackjack
Keno
Craps
Poker
Roulette

The object is to be the player who bankrupts all the others, winning all of the money.

The game contains 100 letter tiles, 50 category tiles, a large 'bucket' to hold the tiles, and a 60 second sand timer.

Before each round, players draw 8 letter tiles from the bucket. A category is drawn.

Players have 60 seconds to form a word from their tiles. A bonus is awarded if the word relates to the category drawn.

A typical game last 10 rounds.

Another expansion to the well known trivia game.
The questions all deal with topics like geography, destinations and other things related to traveling.

The box contains:
 - 2400 questions and answers on
 - 400 cards in
 - 2 plastic boxes.

In this game, you play a powerful lord and his faithful companion engaged in a fight for influence throughout time. The game proceeds simultaneously over three different periods. You start the game in the Middle Ages, on the first of the three game boards (that of the commanderies). With 4 action cards in hand per turn, you have seven turns in which to develop your domains by building various types of military, religious, and civil buildings. Depending on their size, certain buildings are moved in time, which means that they are transferred to the same place on the priories board (Renaissance period) and on the brotherhoods board (modern period), in ruins for military and religious buildings (castles, abbeys…).

Thanks to the watch makers' invention, and with enough money, you can make your two adventurer pawns travel in time… Because if the construction of certain buildings can be profitable, taking over domains on the various boards is essential, since it will allow you to earn bonuses on the 4th and 7th turns and to move ahead of your opponents.

Playing with time is not without consequences, and it can produce surprising results! To give just one example, an abbey created on the priories board could be destroyed by a castle built later in the game in the same place but on the commanderies board, and then moved to the other board… The abbey finally never existed!

On the 4th and 7th turns, each controlled domain generates profits for the players depending on the board. On the the commanderies board, a player who controls a domain militarily, i.e. the one with the biggest military building, will receive the value of the civil buildings in this domain in profits. On the priories board, it is the religious control that will be taken into account. On the brotherhoods board, the players who have best populated the civil buildings and restored the ruins will secure the best profits.

The possibility of destroying and regrouping buildings to unite or divide domains provides a strong and permanent level of interaction between the players.

item.description: Negotiate with the other players the purchase and the sale of goods and become the Great Negotiator. Each player is a merchant. At the beginning, it holds the monopoly of 2 goods and has gold coins. To gain, it must hold 8 different goods and at least 10 parts. For that, exchanges are organized between the players. Simple and original game, Négoces will astonish you by his subtlety. In this play the chance never intervenes, only your direction of the negotiation will enable you to gain.

item.description:
Motomix is a quiz game where all aspects of the long history of motorcycles and motorcycling are covered by over 1.000 questions about bike manufacturers, legendary machines, technological developments, mechanics, sporting events, the great champions...giving you the chance to test your knowledge and discover a wealth of anecdotes !

Then you have to find the best route around the track and the best approach to tackle the different obstacles (double-hump, triple-hump, whoops, table...) in the best conditions...at several points in the race you will be able to slam across your opponents' path with a well-timed block pass and force them to reduce speed by answering correctly to the questions!

From the publisher's website:

Once again, our unfortunate friends find themselves foreigners trapped within the frightful Fortress Furor of the fanged Prince Fieso who would, with felicity, see them flounder and faint. These fine fighters could feasibly face their finish in this forbidding fortification, whose fearsome floors even now flow frighteningly from beneath their feet as the famished Furunkulus forages the fringes, fixing to feast on the foreigners’ flesh. Forthwith, must our fighters fashion their flight from this foulest of fates! But what’s this? By the light of their fallow and flickering flares, our friends find the depths fraught with the most furious of fiends and the fiercest of freaks! With fleet feet, the fearless foreigners follow these ferocious fellows through the fortress, with its multifarious footpaths and their frustrating forks, forging fervently forward toward freedom and fame. Our fighters must not falter from whatever feud or fracas would foil their function: to finally furnish the forlorn Faerie Fabula her freedom from feckless Fieso’s fists!

Theme
Formidable Foes is a light-hearted dungeon crawl. The players all take the role of heroes competing with each other to amass the greatest hoard of treasure. They do this by exploring the dungeon and fighting monsters.

Goal
The goal is to collect as much gold as possible. The winner is the richest player.

Gameplay
On each turn, a player either moves twice; moves once and fights a monster; or collects 'power tokens' which allow a player to improve their dice rolls in subsequent turns. In the early part of the game, the monsters are fairly weak and easily defeated. Defeating a monster increases a character's 'wisdom' which allows them to fight and defeat ever-harder monsters. Fighting monsters involves rolling a dice and then adding power tokens to improve the roll if required.

item.description:
From the box description:
Race to Stardom with the "Fame" gang. Based on the popular TV show.

"You've got big dreams, you want fame."

And right here is where you start playing.

You and your friends race through the N.Y. School of the Arts collecting points as you move towards graduation.

Ages 6 years to adult.

This is a children's game.

The goal is to score points by getting strings of 3, 4, or 5 of your color in a straight line. The game comes with a board with the scoring for both variations written right on the playing surface.

From the back cover of the box:

The Fast Game of Vocabulary, Luck, & Action

Love playing with words but think word games are too slow? 
Then start your mental engines and get ready for Scrosswords, the "un-bored" word game with no board, no waiting, and no end to the fun.
Each round pits one player against all others in a race to discover words in random letter tiles. When you're the Wordsmith, you roll five dice: The black dice determine how many tiles you get - from 4 to 24 - and the red die gives you a chance at a bonus category.

The timer starts as soon as you flip over your tiles. You've got 2 minutes and 30 seconds to form as many words as possible, crossword-style, and earn points for them. Meanwhile all other players - the Scavengers - are furiously writing down all the words you're missing. At the end of the round, tally up you points and see whose words are worth the most!
It takes a combination of luck, skill, and fast reflexes to score big at Scrosswords. And because every turn is different and everyone plays at once, the excitement never slows down!

link.value: Wong & The Design Office, San Francisco

name.value: Blackbeard: The Golden Age of Piracy

item.description:
One of the Avalon Hill games of the early 1990s was Blackbeard, a pirate game totally different from any others available because it simulated the actual life and careers of historical pirates, and how they went about their chosen professions.

Richard Berg has now taken the original and redesigned it, almost entirely, to bring it into line with what gamers like to see and play these days. All those pirates you loved - Black Bart Roberts, Long Ben Avery, Ned Lowe, L'Ollonais, and, of course, Edward Teach (Blackbeard) - 23 in all, are still there, as are the King's Commissioners sent out to stop them. However, the entire play system has been overhauled, and the result is a game that highlights and specializes in player interaction, with almost no down time for any players.

Players represent individual pirates, using them to gain Victory Points by amassing booty and, even more importantly, earning Notoriety for their dastardly deeds. Seizing merchants with cargo ranging from useless paper to the monumental treasure of the Mughal emperors, attacking and sacking ports, fighting storms and scurvy, seeking safe haven in infamous pirate ports such as Tortuga and Madagascar, and, hopefully, using Letters of Marque to retire successfully.

And while the player is doing this, all of the other players, at the same time, are playing their cards and seizing opportunities to stop the pirates. There is a constant interplay among players, and you never know what is going to happen when you set out to do something.

We've simplified movement (no more hexes) and ship battles, we've expanded the use of Royal Navy warships, we've even added individual hostages! (Yes, there is a "Governor's Daughter".)

item.description:
description of the game from LudoArt:

Fragile was designed by Czarné, who also did the graphics for it. A whole slew of crates have arrived at the wharf in Shanghai. Now, this highly fragile cargo must be brought to safety in one's own warehouse as quickly as possible. Problem is, the warehouses are all over the place. Plans are perpetually sent askew, since foreign Chinese workers will often push your crate out from under your nose. Each player controls a team of Chinese workers. Who will be the first to use his team to fill his warehouse with crates - that is, get the most points for fragile cargo? Fragile will please the mind and eye of any strategist.

In a game variant, a little more luck can be added to help things along.

item.description:
From Publisher:

The Monopoly Brand proudly presents the Atlanta Braves™ Collector’s Edition of America’s favorite board game. Braves fans now have the opportunity to buy, sell and trade Braves players, coaches, announcers and team icons. Features legendary Braves players like Hank Aaron, John Smoltz and Andruw Jones. Includes six collectible pewter tokens: Braves hat, batter, pitcher, ball in glove, Georgia dog and the Atlanta Braves tomahawk. With some of the all-time greatest Major League Baseball players and a bright future ahead, the Braves continue to make for exciting play in this timeless game of risk taking and deal making. Bankrupt your opponents in a quest to own the Braves.

From the Publisher:

The MONOPOLY® Brand proudly presents the Boston Red Sox™ Collector’s Edition of America’s favorite board game. We bring Red Sox fans the best of the Red Sox – players, coaches and team icons. Featuring Ted Williams, Jason Varitek and Carlton Fisk, and collectible pewter tokens including a Red Sox hat, batter, pitcher, World Series trophy, Sox and ball in glove. This MONOPOLY Game is a must-have collectible for the die-hard Red Sox fan. This collector’s game captures and brings to life the Red Sox greatest accomplishments including the 1918 and 2004 World Series Championships. Home to some of the most accomplished players in Major League Baseball®, the Red Sox continue to make for exciting play in this classic game of risk taking and deal making

This is a 'press your luck' kind of dice game...

Each person is given two dice (with numbers 1 to 4, two sides have 1's, two sides have 2's), and some chips to begin. Some chips are left in the center to form the 'pot'.

On a person's turn, he/she begins by rolling the 2 dice, examining the sum of the two numbers.

If they add up to 2, that person has been 'stung', and a chip is given to the pot, and play passes to the next player.

If they add up to 8, that person has rolled a 'sting', and gets to take 2 chips from the pot, and play passes to the next player.

If they add up to anything else, that person MUST roll again and try to roll a number equal to, or higher, than the sum of the first roll. At this point ANYONE else playing can also try to roll a sum equal to or higher. Anyone who succeeds gets 2 chips from the pot, anyone who fails loses one. If the active player ends up going it alone, and succeeds, his/her winnings are doubled. Losings are never doubled.

Play ends at a specific number of chips or when the pot is exhausted.

Based on the hit 1960's television series.

From the box:
During the game, a player moves his Pedestrian on the outside path until he reaches a corner space with a Batmobile. He then immediately operates the Batmobile out of the corner space along either path of circles. On his next turn, the player moves his rented Batmobile over the squares of the grid, trying to capture Villains. If the Batmobile goes off the grid (6x6 squares), it jumps to the nearest corner space and the player's turn ends. On his next turn, he moves the Pedestrian again toward another corner with a Batmobile, and another try at capturing more Villains, faster than his opponents.

The object of the game is to be the first player to capture six (6) different Villains.

On The Green Golf is a hole-by-hole simulation that brings together the detail of a shot-by-shot game with the quick-play of a round-by-round game.

Golfers are rated for their ability to reach greens in regulation, going for the green, sand saves, and eagles. Holes are rated for their effect on scoring, and have been painstakingly rated to account for the major hazards and features that will challenge golfers.

The game includes an optional (but highly recommended) weather system that modifies dice rolls for weather and wind, pin placements, and user setting of rough (although a die roll could also make that determination).

There is also a QuickPlay system that allows players the ability to play a round in just three dice rolls for each golfer. This gives players the opportunity to complete entire tournaments in a reasonable amount of time.

And the best part about the QuickPlay system is that you can mix-and-match the three QuickPlay options (full round, nine-hole version, and six-hole version) to QuickPlay some of each round, then switch to the regular game to play out exciting finishes.

The game comes with the following:

-- 2005 men's golfer set (202 cards)
-- Six courses (Augusta, Baltusrol, The Belfry, Pinehurst, Sawgrass, and St. Andrews)
-- Weather and Course Condition Cards
-- Suspense Charts
-- QuickPlay Charts for all six courses
-- Rules

The game is available in two formats:

1) E-Game Format via Hot Stove Games: We send you the files, you print the components using your own equipment or local print shop. E-mail us at hotstovegames@yahoo.com for ordering information.

2) Printed Format via Downey Games: You receive a full-color, printed version of the game with die-cut golfer and course cards, sent to you in a sturdy storage box. Check out the game under "Board Games" at www.downeygames.com

Kings & Castles is a strategic fantasy wargame. From 2-6 players each take one of the kingdoms on the map, are given a king, a prince, a castle, and points to build units, and try to conquer as much territory as possible. At the end of the game victory points are assessed primarily for owned manors and castles.

At the beginning of each game year players receive production points from their manors and spend them on units - in the basic game there are 21 different units that can be purchased, including siege engines and the like. Players then plot the movement of their forces for the 15 turns constituting the year. Orders can be changed under certain circumstances (e.g., if your kingdom is invaded).

Combat is conducted using a deck of cards, with the number drawn for each side being determined by their strengths.

There are some optional rules, including rules for ambushes, capturing enemy leaders, a 7th and 8th player taking the roles of pirates or bandits, and wizards, a new type of unit who can cast a variety of spells and create magical creatures such as dragons.

The game components are:
26-page rulebook
17" x 21.75" color map
50 combat resolution cards
112 very small cardboard chits (16 each in 7 colors, lettered A-P)
2 small black and white copies of the map
2 movement programming sheets
2 dice

name.value: The Conquest and Exploration of Space

item.description:
Conquest is a strategic space exploration and conquest (naturally) game for 2-4 players. Each player starts in a system at a corner of the map and expands outward from there.

Each player represents a different spacefaring race/organization - the Terrans, the Olso Empire, the Federation (changed to the Confederation in the second edition), and the Tholians (changed to the Lothians in the second edition). Each has a different set of units they can build, with varying capabilities - ships are rated for space combat, ground (bombardment) combat, drive system, and what kind of damage they take from the various combat results.

When a star is explored a card is drawn which determines the class of the inhabitable world found there and, if inhabited, its attitude to each of the players. In addition to the attitude the value of each kind of planet varies by player.

There are three different long-range movement systems in the game - warp drive, jump drive (similar to warp drive but much less accurate), and stargates, which have to be built and carried to where you want to use them. Each player uses one of the three systems for their ships.

The second edition, in addition to changing the names of two of the races, changed some of the ship designs which were similar to Star Trek and Star Wars ships. It also changed the name of the game to The Conquest and Exploration of Space.

Chopstick Dexterity MegaChallenge 3000 is a simple but frantic dexterity game in which the object is to collect the most tokens by using chopsticks to pick up the object shown on the token. The theme is presented as a TV game show intended to promote the use of chopsticks among Japanese youth.

To set up, place 25 objects — which comes in five colors and five shapes — in a plastic bowl. Shuffle the tokens face-down, then draw one and reveal it. Tokens show either a specific object or a generic shape in all colors; to win this token, players simultaneously compete to get wooden pieces represented on it. Using only chopsticks, players try to grab specific wooden shapes or colors from a large bowl to their personal target dish. In the three-player game, all players must grab all of the pieces which are either the shape or the color shown on the token. Whoever grabs the most objects wins the token. In a tie, the tied player with the exact shape shown on the token wins.

In the two-player game, the players must grab only the exact piece shown on the token. After each round, the token is awarded and the objects returned to the bowl to start the next round. Play continues until a certain number of tokens are won.

In the solo version, the player is given 75 seconds to remove the pieces from the bowl with their chopsticks to place each piece in a grid with each row given to one of the shapes and each column given to one of the colors.

item.description:
Contents: 1 Wok, 4 Chopsticks, 4 Bowls, Play Food
Object of the game: When the wok is empty, the player with the most food is the winner.

Requires 2 AA batteries. Turn switch on and the wok will start spinning. Use your chopsticks to pick up food from the wok and place into your bowl.

Motor Car Race Game from the early 1930's. The game comes with a four-fold board which has early race car illustrations. The game has four cast lead race car playing pieces. This is a two to six player game . Players spin and then go around the track avoiding penalty places if they can. The game was published by H.P.Gibson & Sons.

From the box:

CONTENTS: 4 Playing Boards, 36 Cards.

HOW TO PLAY: Each player takes a playing board and the smaller cards are placed face down on the table. The youngest player starts by turning over one of the cards and matching it with one of the characters on his playing board. If he cannot, he leaves the card face upwards on the table. The next player may then take this card or selects another. Play continues; should a player turn over a card the he already has, play passes to the next player.

The winner is the first player to cover all his characters on his playing board.

FOR OLDER CHILDREN: If a player picks up a card he does not need he replaces the card face downwards on the table. The other players then have to remember where that card was replaced if they need that particular character.

"Six Men's Morris is played in the same way as Nine Men's Morris, with two changes, the first is that each player has six men and the second is that it is played on [a modified] board (which is similar to that used by Nine Men's Morris, except it lacks the outer set of lines)."

Variation: Five Men's Morris is played on the same modified board, but using 5 men on a side instead of six.

item.description:
Inside the box:

- 4 boards, each with the letters of the alphabet
- 100 subject cards 
- timer
- 110 chips

Idea of the game:

To fill one's own board as quick as possible. Player gets a subject and timer starts. Player tries to say as many words as possible from the given subject in given time. Simultaneously the player covers up the letter on his board with a chip. For example: if the subject is animals in jungle, the players says "ape" and covers letter 'A' in the board. Then the player says "elephant" and covers the letter 'E' and so on.

It sounds easy but the time is limited.

name.value: Monopoly: Chicago White Sox 2005 World Series Champion

item.description:
From the Publisher:

“Let’s Go, Go-Go White Sox!” 2005 marks the year the White Sox™ brought a World Series® Championship back to Chicago and ended an 88 year drought! The MONOPOLY® Brand is proud to present the Chicago White Sox World Series Edition of the world’s most famous board game. This collector’s game captures and brings to life the glory of the 2005 World Series Champions, the Chicago White Sox, featuring photos from the 2005 playoffs. Some of the greatest moments in playoff history have been forever preserved like defeating the defending World Champions Boston Red Sox™ and winning 4 straight games against the Angels™. Players such as Paul Konerko, Mark Buehrle and Jon Garland make for exciting play in this classic game of risk taking and deal making. The tried and true White Sox fan can now buy, sell and trade the best of the 2005 White Sox, in an effort to own and control one of the most famed seasons in White Sox team history.

From the publisher's webpage:

This is the age old game of cat and mouse. A simple but clever two-player game where one player plays the part of a rabbit and the other, the part of two wolves.

The rabbit's job is to hop around the vegetable patch collecting carrots to take back to its burrow, without being eaten by a wolf.

The wolves' job is to sneak around the vegetable patch, to ambush and eat the rabbit.

EDIT: This game was apparently not published in 2007 as planned because of high production costs (per John Yianni on BGG).

Described by the author as a mix between chess and checkers, this game is not for purchase but the rules are freely available [only in French though]. Let's go over a brief overview :

GOAL of the game : 
Surround the opposing King between 4 pieces (Princesses or Pawns) with a minimum of one of your own pieces.

PIECES : 
The King : can't capture/can't be captured/can't jump over pieces and no other piece can jump over the king.

The pawn : you have vertical and horizontal pieces, can capture other pieces. Moves 1 space.

The princess : again : you have vertical and horizontal pieces. May move the full length.

According to the creator, the name of the game has its origins in the French words : Axe [the axis] and Somme [the sum] : the deployment of a pile of piece is determined by the sum of the pieces contained in the same pile.

This means that a pile of 2/3 or 4 pieces will have different powers depending on its number of tiles and will 'break apart' accordingly.

Furthermore, it's an easy game that's also easy explainable and the rules can be found online.

The goal of the game is to complete a circuit in Belgium (for example the gastronomical, sports, touristic, casino or economical circuit) faster than your opponents by traveling from city to city. This is done either by foot, bicycle or car. Money can be earned (to buy a bicycle or car) or lost during the game.

From the Instructions:

Objective: The objective is to save $30, give 10% to the church, then land on the correct Goal square to buy the item shown on your Character Card.

Teaching Goals: The game is based on Lauree & L. Allen Burkett's "Money Matters for Kids" and reinforces that we should tithe/give 10% of our money to the church, set aside 50% of our money in Saving, and spend the remaining 40%. This game demonstrates the importance and benefits of giving to God and emphasizes the value of doing extra to earn money-not just depending on an allowance. Children also learn to count and divide money.

Aimed at: Children aged 5 to 10.

To Play: Roll the die. Move your pawn the number of spaces shown on the die. Follow the rules for each square.
This game from Glevum Games of Gloucester England is a simple roll (spin) and move game similar to many of the times. It features lead racing boats. The game comes from the mid 1930's.

The All-About-Delaware-Game is an educational exploration of the state of Delaware. The large six piece board is a relative map of Delaware's three counties, with parks, natural resources, shopping centers, highways and places of interest noted on the board. Players start at a residence and must travel via dice rolling along the varied highways of Delaware to nine locations, shopping, exploring, and gathering items. The first player to collect travel cards for everything on their list and return to their residence wins.

Four player game. Game comes with four small race car playing pieces. The playing board is divided into 100 squares with a track running through them. Some squares have advantage, some squares have penalties. Roll and move around this track. First player to the finish line wins.

Two player game with the objective being to move all nine of your playing pieces through the bottle neck on the board to the opponents game area. Alternately players roll a die and spend the points to move pieces. Pieces can cross others but must end their move in an empty space. Unlike checkers/draughts, there is no capturing. Game is from Pepys of England and probably originated in the mid 1940's.

item.description: Four player game. Comes with a triple-fold board that shows a map of the World. Progress around the board is determined by advantage and penalty stops. There is no indication of who the designed this game.

This game comes in a box (7¾" x 5¾"). It is a crossword puzzle type game. The game comes with lettered dice which are rolled and then those letters are used to help make a crossword puzzle. The game comes from a company of the same name (DILEX COMPANY) and appears to be from the early to mid 1950's.

This is a British game from the 1960's. It originated from a T.V. show of the same name starring Marion Ryan. The game comes with a 33rpm record with a few bars of 96 tunes the object for the 2 to 12 players is to Spot the Tune. It reminds one of the American TV show called NAME THAT TUNE ( I can name that song in 4 notes ...... etc.)

Who will be first to find his mysterious mythical creature?

The enchanted paths in the mysterious forest change direction again and again. However, with the right knack, enough courage and perseverance, all players will find the shore of the enchanted lake that shows them the way to their destination: a mysterious mythical creature. But this path also holds many magical surprises that may require a detour.

item.description:
Who can change sides with their whole team the quickest?

The crux of the matter: at the end of the game all figures should be standing in exactly the same position but at the other end of the board. Dark or light -- the players' figures intermingle, seemingly randomly on their journey across the board, and they are allowed to jump in any direction that will help them. Using clever tactics helps: the little moves could open up a broader and surprising new perspective. A tactical jumping game for two capricious strategists.

Finding the animals is like looking for a needle in a haystack. You have to observe carefully if you want to succeed in this game of animal hide-and-seek.

When a new enclosed square is formed by the skillful placement or sliding along of the buildings, the successful architect can place a monument in the center of it. Spatial imagination together with well thought out planning are positive advantages in this game for 2 people.

item.description:
Board game based on the old British soap opera. Players take on the role of main characters from the program and attempt to make money out of running a motel.

Ages 4 and up
 Each player chooses a character to represent - Meg, Sandy, Jill or David. Your objective is to promote the three staff pieces under your control to rooms marked on the quarters of the board. Along the way room improvements can take place. Room and Reception Cards may help or hender you! Try not to let the hotel's debts mount up! Have you got what it takes to run a hotel successfully?

"Satisfactory" is a card game that bring the best and worst parts of "White Collar Work" into an interactive card game.

Each player manages a hand of cards consisting of "Hours", "Ladders", "Back-Stabbing" and "Special" cards. On each turn you pay "hours" to place down "ladder" cards trying to climb the corporate ladder to the top. Beware though, as other players can spend their hours to play "Back-stabbing cards trying to either demote your or take credit for your work.

8 random "CEO" cards alter the game dynamics by creating changes and effects to all players.

Each round is considered a week of work, and after 8 weeks the game is over. The "Worker" with the most Ladder Points wins the game.

This is a NON collectible game for 2-6 players for fast paced card action.

The face of the world has changed. Earthquakes have leveled most of the planet. To survive a new form of Architecture called Tectonics has been developed allowing entire cities to be built on hovering pads to avoid the stress and destruction of the almost constant earthquakes and tectonic shift.

The Goal of Tectonic is to be the first player to build a floating city or colony with a population of 12 or more.

Each turn players perform two separate but unique actions trying to collect random City Tiles. Each of these tiles represents a city structure worth 1-3 points. Players may also play cards to add "resident" tokens to their city to build the total population (and score) of the city.

Several cards allow the players to perform espionage either destroying or stealing city tiles and/or residents. (Remember the cities float now.)

Mixed in are world effect cards like an Earthquake and Armageddon which can change the entire face of the Earth (and the game) once again.

This is a NON collectible game consisting of 35 random city tiles, 10 resident tokens, and 104 full color playing cards.

name.value: Lock 'n Load Tactical: Day of Heroes

item.description:
On the afternoon of October 3rd, 1993, a combined force of American Rangers and Delta Force operators dropped into an area of Mogadishu, Somalia, controlled by notorious clan warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid and his loyal militiamen. The Americans’ objective was to capture two of Aidid’s high-ranking lieutenants and get out, but the Aidid and his men had different plans. Two destroyed Black Hawks, 100 American casualties, and twenty-four hours later, the “one-hour” mission ended.

Day of Heroes lets gamers rope down from a Black Hawk with a Chalk of Rangers or step off a Little Bird with Delta Force operators onto the mean streets of Mogadishu, filled with the smell of noxious smoke rising from burning roadblocks, a signal calling Somali militiamen to arms. Play nine scenarios, including the campaign-length scenario, “Day of Heroes”. The Battle of Mogadishu is on, and you can be a part of it.

name.value: World at War: Eisenbach Gap Deluxe Edition

item.description:
It's the summer of 1985 and Soviet tanks stream into West Germany. Thinly spread NATO forces strive to delay the red hordes until reinforcements arrive, and the world watches anxiously, dreading the nuclear weapons held in each super power's arsenal. Welcome to the dark world of Mark H. Walker's Award Winning World at War series.

A platoon level simulation that stresses command, control, and war's unpredictable nature, World At War is an engaging, tactical action game.

The rules cover self-propelled mortars, thin-skinned vehicles, support weapons, ranged combat, opportunity fire, ATGM depletion, assault and overrun combat. Better still, World at War is not just a game, but also a game system. Learn Eisenbach Gap, and you can play any of the follow-on modules.

Reimplemented by Eisenbach Gap Deluxe which also includes Death of the 1st Panzer.

World at War: Death of the 1st Panzer

name.value: A Master Stroke: The Battle for Meiktila, March 5-14, 1945
A Master Stroke: The Battle for Meiktila

item.description:
A Master Stroke: The Battle for Meiktila deals with the British offensive to the railroad town of Meiktila in Burma and the subsequent Japanese counterattack. This was a fight characterized by the bold move made by the 17th Indian Division to abandon their supply lines to take Meiktila, unhinging the Japanese defense line. Relying on air supply to hold out against Japanese attacks, the 17th Indian Division ultimately prevailed.

Scale: Battalion
Game Turn: 1 day/turn

CORX is a 2-4 player strategy board game for players of all ages. The game pieces include a wood game board, 2 dice (for the dice version), and 24 cork games pieces (hence, the name CORX). The instructions detail the dice version of CORX, which adds the element of chance, and the no-dice version (which involves moving your game pieces a pre-determined number of spaces each turn) that will appeal more to the serious chess, checkers, or go players.

The purpose of the game is to march your games pieces across the game board, capturing other players' corx, avoiding capture of your own, and trying to capture another player's "Base".

Game pieces can be moved in any direction. Players can protect their own game pieces by forming "Blocks", and the player who occupies "Center Space" has special privileges.

The game ends when a base is captured, and players then add up their points. The player with the highest score wins (which is often not the player who has ended the game by capturing a Base).

"Match" play involves playing 3 games, with the person who has the most match points winning the Match. Match points are awarded for each game won, and for having the most total game points. It is highly recommended that CORX be played in matches, as that adds another strategic dimension to the game. Because the winner of a match is determined by who has the most "match points" (instead of whoever wins 2 out of 3 games), players need to assess the "big picture" before making the decision to end a game.

Corx with dice works best with 3-4 players. Corx without dice works best with 2-3 players.

A simple game published by the German City of Paderborn. By playing the players get to know a little bit about the city and its shops.
During each players' turn they roll a six-sided dice to move along a game-board depicting a map of Paderborn. At certain spaces players can acquire cards of the shops or they can go sightseeing by following the instructions on the back of the card. Sometimes there is only information written, sometimes you have to pay an amount of money or at other times you may earn some cash.
The game ends when the last player reaches the finish space with his playing piece. The winner is the person who has acquired the most sightseeing and/or shop cards.

Knowalot is a fun new trivia game with a difference. Each question card has a short summary of a well-known subject but with key words and phrases missing. All you have to do is fill in the blanks. The subject could be anything from the Spice Girls to the Space Race.
How do you play Knowalot?
You read out the subject on the card. Everyone then bids on how many they think they'll get right out of five possible answers. A question on your favorite movie, bid five. If you get all five right, you win a brain, five brains and you've won!

EQUID is a captivating board game which brings you the thrill of a day at the races. Place your bets on a horse and try to make it win using a mixture of general knowledge, tactics and judgment.
EQUID takes the form of a race in which any player can move any horse without knowing who has bet on which. At the start of the game the players study the cards they have been dealt and place secret bets: either a straight win bet or a combination bet. Each player in turn answers general knowledge questions about horses, and can play a card to accelerate a horse, until two horses have crosses the finishing line.
The wide variety of cards and the color and position of the horses give the players unlimited scope for tactics and last-minute gallops to the finishing post !
The appeal of EQUID is that the game is a mixture of bluff, astute card playing, tactics and general knowledge, without forgetting an element of chance to spice up the game and create an enjoyable atmosphere and some unforgettable moments !
The game covers every aspect of a horse and its universe, with over 1100 questions about ethology, anatomy, racing, techniques, equipment, health, feeding, sporting events... to test your knowledge and bring you a wealth of interesting facts and amusing anecdotes !

"Get ready to play The Big Taboo...

The Big Taboo is one mix between from the traditional Taboo, Taboo Body Talk and Taboo Quick Draw. The play mixes oral tests, mime and drawing. The general principle remains very near to the basic play of the Taboo game. Just like the Taboo you know and love, but with 4 unspeakable ways to play! Race against the timer to get as many guess words as possible. Will you have to draw them, use as few words as possible to describe them, play Classic Taboo or twist Bendy Bob to help your team guess them? You even have a chance at a brain-bending memory round!"

Following in the footsteps of Cranium, The Big Taboo is attempting a new lease at life through adding extra mechanics and expanding the basic concept of the original game with variants.

name.value: Your Best Life Now: The Game

item.description:
From the publisher's website:
"The best selling book is now an
at-home experience like no other!

“Your Best Life Now” by Joel Osteen has sold over 3 million copies and has been on the New York Times and Publisher’s Weekly Best Seller list for over 50 consecutive weeks. The game enables players to step beyond the one-on-one nature of the book and feel, touch, and live Joel’s 7 Steps To Living At Your Full Potential with your friends and family. Your Best Life Now: The Game is an entertaining and educational way to take inventory of yourself and accountability of your actions. Climb the mountain as you

• Enlarge Your Vision

• Develop a Healthy Self Image

• Discover the Power of your Thoughts and Words

• Let Go of the Past

• Find Strength Through Adversity

• Live To Give

And • Choose to Be Happy

Each new plateau represents a challenge and a chance to open up and experience these steps first hand as you learn to live Your Best Life Now.

Produced by the bookstore chain Chapters in Canada, this is a trivia game with 3,000 questions in five categories: Fiction and Literature, Classics, Non-Fiction, Children's Literature, and Canadian Literature.

The Battle of Hastings was the most decisive Norman victory in the Norman conquest of England. On October 14, 1066, the Normans of Duke William of Normandy (aka "Guillaume Le Conquérant" in French, "William the Conqueror" in English) defeated the Anglo-Saxon army led by King Harold II.

item.description:
1967 3M TEACH KEY Reading and Spelling. Scarce 3M EduPLAYtional game. Triangular shaped box. This game is in the same series as Egghead and Chicken.

Includes 2 packs of 24 key cards (48 total), the house board, box, and set of keys. I do not know if add-on card sets were available, although it is possible.

Players ages 5-8 insert the key into the correct missing letter hole of each word in order to correctly spell and thus unlock the word.

From Publisher's Site:

Do you have the instinctive genius of Larry Bird? School your opponents in this Boston Celtics Collector’s Edition of America’s favorite board game, MONOPOLY. Buy, sell, and trade the all-time greatest Celtics including Bill Russell, Larry Bird, Bob Cousy, Paul Pierce, Ryan Gomes, and Delonte West. Own timeless moments of Celtics history like the 1968-1969 NBA Championship when the team clinched their 11th title in 13 years. In addition to owning the greatest assets of the most storied franchise in NBA history, this special edition includes six collectible pewter tokens, featuring the Celtics clover, Basketball Hoop, NBA basketball, NBA Championship Trophy, player shooting, and defensive player.

Koom Valley Thud is a more balanced game that uses the same bits as Thud. This time the dwarves are trying to escape from the Koom Valley with the Rock. 
Rules can be found on Thud site ( http://www.thudgame.com/kvt )

item.description:
description of the game from LudoArt:

Chicago, 1925. It is the time of Prohibition. 4 opposing gangs, each with 9 gangsters want to bring the city under their control. By playing out rows, each of which consist of 6 gangsters, players try to gain a majority through their most valuable gangsters. But careful! To gain powerful positions, sometimes sharpshooting is needed. The goal of the game is to become the most powerful of all, Al Capone. Tactics, strategy and cold-bloodedness will be required if you want to be celebrated as the boss of bosses in this game.

What gives the game its flair, apart from the real metal munitions, is the deft touch of the illustrator as well as court artist Robert Nippoldt. From corrupt mayor William Hale "Big Bill" Thompson to Boss of Bosses Al "Scarface" Capone, all of the major gangsters of this lead-filled time are represented. The well-known portraits are taken from the eponymous book "Gangster. The Bosses of Chicago" by Robert Nippoldt, and give the game a sheen of authenticity. The book has received awards from the German Designer Club, Buchkunst Fund as well as the Red Dot Design Award 2006.

Expanded by: Gangster: Der Clou.

item.description:
From the back of the box:

This is a tabletop battle game for two players, where you command the Space Marines, the power-armored defenders of Humanity, or the Genestealers, a strange alien race bent on the destruction of the galaxy spanning Imperium of Man.

What You Get in This Box:

- 5 Space Marines (4 with boltguns and 1 with missile launcher) for you to assemble and paint.
- 8 alien Genestealers for you to assemble and paint
- a 24-pages booklet with game rules, background information, painting and modeling instructions, and tactical advice 
- a die
- 7 water-based acrylic paints 
- a paint brush

Every player undertakes a road trip through the USA. While traveling the player's goal is to visit all locations as fast as possible. To prove this to the other players every player has to get a postcard from each location.
The players have to answer questions whenever they don't land on a location, but on an open field. The cards have questions divided into three categories: easy, medium, hard. All questions are in English and you have to answer in English (note that this is a German game).
If a player hits a special location, he takes the postcard from that location, reads it out aloud and places it in front of him. Whoever visits all 15 locations first wins.

Players each control two piggy banks which race around a track to the finish line. On their turn the players roll a die containing the numbers one through three and then choose one of their two pigs to move that many spaces, skipping over spaces already occupied with a pig. Along the way pigs will stop on spaces which earn them gold coins for their banks, spaces which allow them to put black coins worth -1 gold in their opponents banks, and spaces which allow them to shake their opponents' banks so as to try and gauge how many coins they hold.

The first five pigs to cross the finish line earn five, four, three, two and one coins, after which the game is over and all the piggy banks are opened. The player who owns the bank with the most gold wins.

A vanity press publication from New Zealand in 2000.

From the box: Search the Egyptian sands for ancient treasures, face terrible monsters, treacherous traps and curses. Employ dastardly schemes to profit from your opponents. Steal their treasure, assassinate their guides, corrupt their bodyguards, dabble in the ancient arts of magic... But watch your back! In the desert everyone is digging for treasure. Trust no-one, not even your camel!

Players cross the Serengeti searching for the 'Big Five'.
They'll only be successful if they pay close attention to the DVD (featuring over 200 video clips) and are able to answer questions related to what's shown on the DVD.

Game originally published completely in Dutch, but an English language version "Wildlife: DVD Board Game" became available in 2007. The game comes in an impressive embossed tin box.

Answering questions on the DVD allows one to collect cards which in turn allows your truck to move around the board.

Subtitled "The Thrilling Pie Filling Game." Each player has a set of marbles and tries to fill in one of six sections of a plastic pie while it rotates.

Pirate Arithmetics

The pirates have discovered a treasure chest! But how to divide up the booty? Very easy, the pirate, cleverest and quickest at arithmetic gets the most gold coins! The arithmetic disk shows the right result. A game collection about addition, subtraction and multiplication for 2 - 4 arithmetical pirates. 
With increasing degrees of difficulty.

Ages 6-99.

item.description: Polygon is a four sided Chess variation similar in appearance to Helios from the same designer. Each piece has specific moves, and players attempt to capture the O piece of the opposing player. Two players play one color each on opposite sides of the board, three players play one color each, and four players play as partners.

Farmer Fred feeds his chickens early in the morning. With a sweeping gesture, he throws the grains over the fence. With loud cackles and lots of flapping, the chickens lunge for the tidbits. But then the fox appears around the fence....

A skillful game with great bits, as typical of Haba.

item.description:
The Wolf Game contains five dice, with a wolf replacing the "1" on each. Players take 3 turns rolling dice, scoring by multiplying the number of wolves by the total of the remaining dice. If 2 or more are rolled, a pack is formed, and a wolf is passed to the next player.

The instructions also include a numbers of "wolf facts."

Louise packs eggs, apples, and bread into her basket. "Do we have all we need?", she asks. "No", yells Samuel as he rushes for milk and cheese. In the different game variations children will recognize groceries by touching, assigning and finding them, helped by a good memory.

Great looking wooden food, too!

The game is a variation of TicTacToe. Players play six games and score points. There are 16 ceramic tiles one inch square. 4 black with “X”, 4 black with “XO”, 4 white with “X” and 4 white with “XO”. There are no tiles with just “O”. Players score points by making a line of three tiles of same color (25 pts), 3 Xs or 3 XOs in a line of two colors (50 pts), 3 Xs or 3 XOs of same color in a line (100 pts).

The game is in a pasteboard box about 4½ inches square and ½ inch thick. The rules are on the outside bottom of the box. The 3x3 square game board included is a piece of cardboard about 4 inches square. The center square of the board has a note that it is not to be used for the first play of a game. The game has 8 ceramic tiles (1 inch square) for each player.

Game box lists copyright as being held by CowoC, Inc. and the back of the box states that the distributor is The Good Ideas Co., PO Box 3512 Madison, WI 53704

This is a game that helps teach children counting skills.

From the back of the box:

Count the objects on each card, then identify and assemble each matching pair. The cards are uniquely cut so that only the correct matches will fit. The game is over when all pairs are matched. Everyone wins!

item.description:
Der Knizia Almanach (the Knizia Almanac), published by German game journal Spielbox, focuses on designer Reiner Knizia and his (many) games. The Almanac includes an expansion to Blue Moon City.

The almanac also contains the game Olix which was published in an earlier Spielbox magazine issue.

(Note that this product is in German, with an English translation available online at http://www.spielbox.de/pdf/knizia.pdf.)

Founded in BGG thread http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1105433#1105433 Drop Weasel is a game created [i]ad hoc[/i] at dark:thirty.

Can you be the best weasel? Compete for mice, rats, and other rodents, as well as fish, frogs, and birds' eggs! You assign dice to food sources, but what will they roll? Can you keep enough dice in play to react to opponents and win?

Components include a food control map, player mats, and different colored dice for each player.

Long Live the King is a game set in the court of a medieval kingdom. The game covers the court conflicts and intriques in anticipation of the old King's demise. In a fragile monarchy, each member of the court will scheme to achieve as much influence on the coming succession as possible. And if victory seems impossible, it might be time to plan your revenge.

There are seven unique characters in the game, each with its own special abilities and victory conditions. The King can be played by a Game Master but this is not mandatory, though reccomended. More players can act the roles of minor character, roleplaying the effects of the various cards being played. The seven unique characters are:

 Ambassador
 Archbishop
 Baron
 Queen
 Royal Bastard
 Steward
 Treasurer




Long Live the King is a live-action strategy game that blends diplomacy and backstabbing with strategic control of cards and limited ressources. During the game, each player will receive money and intrique cards and use these to increase their favor with the king, make alliances with other player or further their own goals. But as each player has a unique victory condition, alliances never lasts long in the court of the king. There are three distinct phases in the game, in the Audience phase ressources are distributed, in the Diplomacy phase off-table diplomacy occurs and finally the Council Phase is where players will make and discuss petitions. There is also a heavy emphasis on roleplaying, and each card and ability is recommended to be acted out by the players, as the King can grant Favor to those who perform particularly dramatic or cunning.

Game Components:

 31-page Rulebook
 Seven Player Portfolios
 Royal Bag of Coin
 Coins of the Realm
 200 cards divided into six different types

item.description: The object of this game is to maintain the balance of poor Willi who is at the top of the ladder painting; you continually add paint buckets and hope he doesn't tip over.

This is a set of 6 educational card games based on the famous phonics learning method. The individual card game names are In The Beginning, Silent Partners, Copy Cats, Double Trouble, Odd Balls, and Divide and Conquer.
Similar concept to Hungry Hungry Hippos. Four players manipulate their squirrel's arms to catch the nuts that fall from the central tree.

item.description:
Astoria is two games in one : the board introduces a game named 'Combination Version' on one side, and another game named 'Epic Version' on its other side.

Each version game puts the players in the role of powerful mages and alchemists, who are trying to find a cure to the strange and sudden illness that stroke the king of Astoria. 
 
The material included (four glass flasks, 60 shining gems in six colors, 66 cards) is used differently, depending on the game played.

The Combination Version is team-played. By placing gems, players put in place the components that will make them able to produce one of many different magic components. Those components will be used as reagents in the cure.

When playing, a player merely chooses an action among three :

 draw a new card
 add a gem to the pattern, trying to put a reagent in play
 move a gem on the pattern to another place, thus producing an 'alchemy reaction'.




The players use alchemy powers to prevent the opposing team from putting their reagents in play, or to speed up their own production, in order to produce the best cure for the king and be rewarded accordingly. The game ends as soon as one category of gems is depleted, so it is important to delay the end of the game if your team hasn't found the best cure yet.

The other side of the board presents a completely different game named the "Epic Version", that includes more diplomacy and roleplaying features.

Players are powerful mages trying to save the city of Astoria from three disasters : a barbarian invasion, a revolt, and the wrath of a powerful dragon. They develop their powers by creating magic items and putting them in play. Magic items are from six different magic sources, and each source can be used for a different effect on the city. The players use those magical forces to fight off the barbarians and defend the city from the besieging forces. The barbarian hordes will also be reinforced by war chiefs and sorcerers that will add to the pressure on the city.

The players objective is still to find a cure to the illness of the king of Astoria. But some of the mages are also traitors, trying to lead the king to his final rest and give victory to one of the enemies of Astoria. Players have to watch each other, and may accuse another mage of treachery. They also have to keep an eye for the king's health, for if he dies, everything will be lost for the defenders.

The game has different endings : the king can die, or can be saved. Or the city may fall to the hands of one of the enemies of Astoria. If one of the enemy factions comes to its maximal force, the game immediately ends with the victory of this faction (and, possibly, the victory of the traitor that was secretly supporting it!).

Both the Combination and the Epic Versions use a scoring method that makes it possible for players to play the game in competition and tournaments.
